Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Youth A has been having sex with Staff 1 who is in his 40's. Youth
A and Staff 1 may be in a relationship but that has not been
confirmed. Staff 1 gave Youth A a hoodie that she wears all the
time, and she gets special privileges like going shopping.
Investigation Administrator was interviewed face to face at the facility on
11/17/23. She reported Youth A has been moved to another
facility and Staff 1 is not working with female youth at the facility.
This move is part of the safety plan and until given clearance by
MDHHS, Staff 1 will avoid all contact with female youth.
Complainant was interviewed via phone on 11/20/23. She
reported having no further information to provide on the
allegations. She also reported receiving the allegations from Youth
B who is currently in Complainant’s care at a new facility. Youth B
told Complainant Youth B is not really sure if the allegations are
true but reported the allegations to Complainant because Youth B
was “just worried”.
Foster Care Worker was interviewed via phone on 11/20/23.
She reported Youth A is on Foster Care Worker’s caseload and
Youth A has a history of accusing others of inappropriate
behavior. This is Youth A’s common behavior and when things
don’t go Youth A’s way in a placement, Youth A will claim
something happened. Youth A also has a history of “liking older
men” and will go AWOL if given the chance. Foster Care Worker
also reported hearing about the “hoodie” but understands all staff
gave Youth A something while in care.
Youth A was interviewed face to face at the new facility on
11/17/23. She is now lodged at Vista Maria and reported feeling
2

safe. She also reported being well taken care of and having no
issues with the new placement. Youth A was interviewed at
CARE House of Oakland County on 11/28/23 in collaboration
with MDHHS worker and Law Enforcement. Youth A reported
liking to bond with staff members and identified Staff 1 as a staff
liked. Youth A liked Staff 1 because of the way he dressed but
denied any more of a relationship with Staff 1 or any other staff at
the facility. Youth A also reported receiving items from staff at the
facility and that Staff 1 informed Youth A that if Youth A graduated
high school, he would obtain a pair of shoes for Youth A. Each of
the items Youth A received from staff were presented as a reward
for some positive behavior from Youth A. Youth A denied being
close to any of the staff at the facility. Youth A reported Youth B
started spreading rumors about Supervisor 2 and Youth C
because Youth B was upset the male youth would not speak to
Youth B. Youth A also reported the rumors were untrue.
Supervisor 1 was interviewed face to face at the facility on
11/28/23 in collaboration with MDHHS worker. He reported not
being aware of the allegations and then stated Staff 1 is “one of
the best staff at the facility”. Supervisor 1 reported Staff 1 has
donated clothing for youth but nothing specific for a specific youth.
When other staff provide food or candy it is for their incentive
program and to help motivate youth to develop appropriate
behaviors/responses. Staff will always let Supervisor 1 know
(getting his permission) when they are providing an extra incentive
for the youth. Supervisor 1 reported rotating staffing assignments
to keep staff and youth from developing favoritism and if he
suspects favoritism maybe occurring, Supervisor 1 will address
the concern with staff and not assign that specific youth to the
specific staff. Supervisor 1 also understands Youth A had a history
of behaviors that he wanted to avoid so he never assigned Staff 1
to work with Youth A. The facility ratio is one staff to two youth and
Staff 1 never worked with Youth A even though Youth A had
asked to have Staff 1 assigned Youth A. Youth A had wanted a
male staff, but Supervisor 1 engaged in preventive safety planning
and didn’t allow a male staff to work with Youth A. The only
contact Staff 1 would have with Youth A was if they crossed paths
in the dining room, otherwise they would never be in the same
room.
Staff 1 was interviewed face to face at the facility on 11/28/23
in collaboration with MDHHS worker. He reported not knowing
the full allegations and when told, Staff 1 denied the allegations.
He also reported Youth A found out Staff 1 donates clothing and
picked out an item (hoodie), but he didn’t give Youth A the hoodie
3

personally. The facility has a clothing room and youth are allowed
to pick out clothing as needed. Staff 1 reported working part-time
at a clothing store so he has access to clothing to donate to the
program. He denied every being assigned to work directly with
Youth A and was unsure how long Youth A was in the program at
the facility.
Supervisor 2 was interviewed via phone on 12/12/23 in
collaboration with MDHHS worker. He reported having no
concerns with Staff 1 nor any other staff. He had no knowledge of
any romantic relationships between staff and youth and would
take appropriate action if believing something is occurring. He
denied any inappropriate relationships between himself and youth.
He also reported gifts for youth have to be approved by
administration even if staff want to reward a youth with “chips”. In
regard to social media, he denied ever showing any youth social
media and he was able to identify the policy restricting staff
showing social media to youth. The gift of clothing is provided to
youth who enter the program without the necessary clothing and
again all items provided must be approved by administration.
Documents Reviewed:
Youth B interview by DCWL Worker 1 on 11/20/23 at Youth
B’s new facility. Youth B reported being at the same facility as
Youth A until Youth A left. Youth B reported hearing rumors that
Youth A and Youth C were having relations (sex) with Supervisor
1 but was told by Youth C some of the rumors were untrue. Youth
B also reported being told by Youth C that Youth A was having
relations with Staff 1, but Youth B never witnessed any
inappropriate behavior between staff and youth. Youth B reported
Youth C denied the rumors of a relationship with Supervisor 2.
Youth B reported Youth A would call Supervisor 1 “fine” and Youth
A told Youth B that Supervisor 2 shared his social media and
personal information with Youth A. Since Youth A left the facility,
the rumors stopped.
Youth C interview by DCWL Worker 1 on 11/20/23 at Youth
C’s new facility. Youth C reported being at the facility during the
same time Youth A was in the facility and both knew each other.
Youth C also denied Youth A had any relationship with any
specific staff. Youth C denied Staff 1 gave Youth A a hoodie or
anything else. Female staff would bring the female youth items
such as perfume or snacks. Youth C denied ever hearing about
any youth being in a romantic relationship with any of the staff at
the facility.
4

Email from GAL dated 11/16/2023. It is documented Youth A is
not always trustworthy or truthful in making statements and
accused her prior foster parents of sexual abuse which were
unfounded.
Oakland County Sheriffg Office Case Report dated
11/17/2023. Law Enforcement outlines the interview of Youth A at
CARE House of Oakland County and concludes there is no
evidence to support the allegations, so the case is closed for Law
Enforcement. There is no observations, evidence, or statements
of sexual or physical abuse disclosed during Youth A’s interview.
Oakland County Children’s Village Employee – Resident
Relationships dated 5/18/2022. This document outlines the
expectations of staff when interacting with youth in the program.
Staff are not to give or receive personal gifts from youth nor their
families unless prior administrative approval is obtained. If staff
are providing gifts to the entire youth group, this is deemed
acceptable but still requires supervisory approval. Staff are not to
share personal details with youth nor send letters or notes to
youth or receive letters or notes from youth.
Oakland County Children’s Village Phone Use dated
6/22/2022. This document outlines the use of company and
personal cell phones. Staff are not to use their personal cell phone
or smart watch while on duty and responsible for the supervision
of youth. Cell phones are also not to be left unattended or charged
in locations that are visible and accessible to residents. Also, the
viewing and/or participating in movies, games, or social media on
personal electronic devices is strictly prohibited.
Human Resources file for Staff 1 was reviewed. Staff 1 was
hired on 9/14/2009 and became a full-time employee on 6/1/2014.
Documentation indicates Staff 1 is current on his training and last
completed trauma training on 6/30/23, Behavior management
training on 7/20/23, and civil rights on 5/8/23. There is no
documentation of disciplinary action (verbal or written) in the file.
Human Resources file for Supervisor 2 was reviewed.
Supervisor 2 was hired on 1/2/2023 and there is no
documentation of disciplinary action (verbal or written) in the HR
file for Supervisor 2. Supervisor 2 is current on his training and
last completed Ethics and Boundaries for staff training on
3/17/2023.
5

Analysis Based upon interviews and written documentation there is no
evidence that supports Staff 1 engaged in inappropriate behaviors
with Youth A. There is no evidence Staff 1 provided a “hoodie” to
Youth A personally nor is there evidence Youth A and Staff 1 were
in a romantic relationship. There was no evidence that Supervisor
2 had inappropriate contact with youth.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. It is recommended that the current license status be
continued.

sir_summary.summary: A special investigation was conducted into allegations that a youth (Youth A) had an inappropriate sexual relationship with a staff member (Staff 1) at Children's Village and received special treatment, including a gifted hoodie. The investigation, which included interviews with involved youth, staff, supervisors, and a review of documentation, found no evidence to substantiate the allegations; Youth A denied the claims, the complaining source recanted, and the facility had safety protocols in place to prevent such contact. The report concludes that the facility is in compliance with all rules and no violations were established.
